title-group.article-title: Television Broadcast Demand in Markets Without Local Teams

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Recreation, Sport and Tourism, University of Illinois, Champaign, IL, USA
2School of Kinesiology and Recreation, Illinois State University, Bloomington, IL, USA

author-notes.corresp: Scott Tainsky, 104 Huff Hall, MC-584, Champaign, IL 61820, USA Email: tainsky@illinois.edu

fn.p: Scott Tainsky is an assistant professor of sport management at the University of Illinois. He received his PhD from the University of Michigan in 2008.

Chad D. McEvoy is an associate professor and coordinator of the sport management program at Illinois State University. His research interests are focused on revenue generation in spectator sport and he is currently serving as co-editor of the Journal of Issues in Intercollegiate Athletics.

abstract.p: This article uses television ratings from the 2006 and 2007 National Football League (NFL) seasons to estimate viewer demand in large markets without local teams. The factors that are found to be statistically significant and positively related determinants of television ratings are: team quality and age; the closest team in proximity to the market; late-season contests; and having teams such as the Cowboys and Patriots as participants. Concurrent game telecasts and contests involving unevenly matched teams are negatively related to viewership.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The National Football League (NFL) receives more than $3.7 billion annually in television broadcasting revenue (Badenhausen, Ozanian, & Settimi, 2009). On a per team basis, each NFL franchise receives approximately $116 million per year in national television revenue. To put this into perspective, the average National Hockey League (NHL) franchise generated just $92 million in total revenue in 2007-2008 and the entire NHL collectively earned less than $200 million per year in national television broadcasting contracts from both the United States and Canada (NHL Team Valuations, 2008). The popularity and success of the NFL is such that the league’s television contract provides its member teams a stable financial base before ever selling a single ticket, hot dog, or licensed sweatshirt. The NFL’s national television deals represent more than four times the revenues generated by the National Basketball Association (NBA) or Major League Baseball (MLB). Table 1 presents a comparison of national television revenues for the four major North American team sports leagues.

caption.p: National Television Revenues for North American Professional Team Sports Leagues

fn.p: Note: Data above includes national network and cable agreements but not DirecTV and other subscriber agreements. Data is approximate and based on information published in a variety of media outlets.

sec.p: Given the billions of dollars involved annually, it is imperative that the NFL and its television partners make sound choices regarding which games to televise, both on national and regional broadcasts. Failing to broadcast games in highest demand inevitably leads to suboptimal viewership and television ratings, which affects a number of the league’s most significant stakeholders. This hurts both the television networks and their local affiliates as ratings correspond with future advertising prices. Suboptimal viewership and ratings also hurt the NFL and its teams in negotiations for future television contracts. This study quantifies the importance of various factors in estimating broadcast ratings in markets without NFL teams, where all of the games televised can be selected to maximize expected viewership.

sec.title: NFL Television Contracts and Broadcast Scheduling
sec.p: The NFL franchises collectively pool their television rights and sell those rights nationally to multiple television networks. The only broadcast rights sold individually by franchises are for local radio and locally distributed preseason television broadcasts. The majority of the league’s games are played on weekend afternoons, with just one national telecast on Sunday and Monday nights. On each of five successive Thursday and three Saturday nights late in the 2006 and 2007 regular seasons, which we study here, the league staged one contest. The eight game Run to the Playoffs package has since been renamed the Thursday Night Football Special Edition. Modified to comply with the league’s antitrust exemption prohibiting Saturday games during the NCAA football season, in 2010 the package aired seven games on Thursday nights and one on Saturday night. Forgoing the rights fee for this package, the games have been aired on the channel owned by the league, NFL Network. Nationally four networks share the remaining games, along with DirecTV, which pays for the rights to broadcast Sunday afternoon games not available on local affiliates and sells those rights to its customers for a premium. Table 2 displays a summary of these packages.

fn.p: Note: The NFL Network is a subsidiary of the NFL, which is why the network does not pay the league a rights fee. The data above does not include the $700 million/year paid to the league by DirecTV for the rights to sell subscriptions to DirecTV customers for coverage of Sunday afternoon broadcasts not shown by local network affiliates. AFC = American Football Conference; NFC = National Football Conference.

sec.p: CBS and FOX currently hold the rights for the NFL’s afternoon broadcasts. Among them, CBS has the American Football Conference (AFC) package, meaning that it has the rights to broadcast nonprime time games between two AFC teams or, in the case of interconference games, those games in which the visitor is from the AFC. Similarly, FOX holds the National Football Conference (NFC) package, involving non prime time games between two NFC teams or interconference games in which the visitor is an NFC team. During each of the first 16 (of 17) weeks of the NFL regular season, the two networks each broadcast two games on eight Sundays and one game on the other eight Sundays on a rotating basis so that three games are available between the two networks each Sunday afternoon. Both CBS and FOX broadcast doubleheaders during the final week of the regular season.

Each of the Sunday afternoon broadcasts on CBS and FOX is distributed regionally to local network affiliates. Local affiliates in NFL franchise markets broadcast the game of the team located in that market unless the game falls under the league’s blackout rule, meaning the game is not sold out more than 48 hours prior to its scheduled starting time. For other regional broadcasts, games are selected by CBS and FOX with the input of their local affiliates, typically considering factors such as the game’s national appeal and the geographic proximity of the teams involved. Because the home team presumably commands a premium and games are generally not televised opposite a local game, the decision on what games to air takes on added importance in markets without an NFL team.

sec.title: Demand for Sport
sec.p: Borland and Macdonald (2003) identify five primary categories of demand determinants in sports as they relate to attendance—form of consumer preferences, price, viewing quality, characteristics of the contest, and supply capacity. Because this construct is created to model attendance, the theoretical specification must be modified for television viewership. Price should be dropped for two reasons. One reason is because the monetary cost associated with television viewership is negligible. The second is that the time investment is approximately constant across all contests, once one has accounted for seasonal differences. Therefore, even if the ratings metric did not deflate the number of viewers by air time, it would not affect the time cost of viewership as an input. Similarly viewing quality—defined as stadium and seat quality—is not meaningful with respect to television viewership. Likewise, stadium capacity has no bearing on audience size as the number of spectators in one of Nielsen’s designated market areas (DMAs) is limited only by the number of viewers in that area (and this too is accounted for by the use of ratings as opposed to total viewers tuning into a particular broadcast). Accordingly, demand for broadcast of sport focuses on consumer preferences and game characteristics.

While the research on demand for sports is vast, little attention has been given to broadcast demand. Possible reasons for the extensive scholarship on demand for sport include the uniqueness of the sport product, the importance of understanding demand for sport among both practitioners and scholars in sport, and the objectively measureable and nonproprietary nature of sport industry data. An examination of the economics-oriented and econometrics-based demand literature reveals that a multitude of studies utilize attendance as proxy for demand. Beginning with the seminal work of Noll (1974), these works examine attendance factors extensively in a wide variety of sport settings, including baseball (e.g., Kahane & Shmanske, 1997; McDonald & Rascher, 2000; Schmidt & Berri, 2001), American football (e.g., Depken, 2001; Kaempfer & Pacey, 1986), European football/soccer (e.g., Simmons, 1996; Szymanski, 2001; Szymanski & Smith, 1997), and many others.

Several demand studies examine television viewership as a factor potentially influencing attendance (Allan & Roy, 2008; Baimbridge, Cameron, & Dawson, 1995; Bruggink & Eaton, 1996; Carmichael, Millington, & Simmons, 1999; Garcia & Rodriguez, 2002; McEvoy & Morse, 2007; Price & Sen, 2003; Welki & Zlatoper, 1999). In summary, these studies show mixed results in examining the relationship between telecasts and attendance, finding positive and negative relationships or no relationship at all.

Few studies, however, utilize television viewership as a measure of demand. Forrest, Simmons, and Buraimo (2005) and Alavy, Gaskell, Leach, and Szymanski (2010) use television ratings as a proxy for demand in examinations of the relationship between demand and outcome uncertainty in European football/soccer. Forrest et al. (2005) study game-by-game television ratings and broadcasters' choice of which games to televise in the EPL from 2002-2005, including explanatory variables commonly used in attendance-based demand studies. These include day of the week, time of the season, and the strength of the two teams playing in each game. The research finds that uncertainty and team strength are correlated with increased viewership and likelihood of the game being broadcast. Alavy et al. (2010) examine the impact of outcome uncertainty on television ratings within contests on a minute-by-minute basis, finding that uncertainty and games not ending in a draw generated more viewers. Hausman and Leonard (1997) investigate the relationship between star players and television ratings in the NBA in the early 1990s. Controlling for demand factors such as day of week, month of year, start time, team quality, and concurrent telecasts, the study finds that television ratings increased dramatically when NBA stars such as Michael Jordan, Magic Johnson, and Larry Bird were playing. Kanazawa and Funk (2001) and Aldrich, Arcidiacono, and Vigdor (2005) also utilize television ratings as a measure of demand in examinations of the impact of athletes' race on demand in the NBA and NFL, respectively. Finally, Tainsky (2010) uses Nielsen ratings to estimate demand for local NFL games and finds similarities in the parameter estimates between home and away markets. Further, the research also shows that factors such as the quality of teams and whether a game was broadcast during the evening prime time are associated with increased television ratings in the NFL, while income is negatively related to viewership. No study was identified, however, that examines factors influencing demand in markets without teams.

Understanding what motivates fans in markets without teams is a central to estimating the value of the broadcast rights sold by the NFL and purchased by television networks. The rights to the Sunday afternoon broadcasts include several types of telecasts. For a given network the value of the rights can be described as the cumulative value of the home teams' broadcasts in their local markets, the away teams' broadcasts in their local markets, games in which the local team is not represented in cities with NFL teams, and broadcasts of games in areas without a local team. Tainsky (2010) examines the first two items, while the last two have yet to be studied. This research studies the last item exclusively, a previously unexplored area of the fan population and sports-demand literature representing more than half of the U.S. population.

sec.title: Data
sec.p: Summary statistics of data collected for the 2006 and 2007 NFL seasons and are presented in Table 3 . These data include all Sunday afternoon games broadcast on CBS and FOX in each respective designated market area. While the process of game selection for the games appear on Sunday and Monday evenings is an interesting one, this study focuses on the narrower issue of game selection from among the slate of games that are eventually made available to the networks for broadcast on Sunday afternoons. In a typical week, there are 14 games played on Sunday afternoons. The majority of games are contested simultaneously across the United States during the earlier of the two time slots. The late games tend to take place in cities in the Western United States so that the local kickoff time is not before noon. The markets used in the analysis are Los Angeles, Orlando, Sacramento, Portland, Hartford, Raleigh-Durham, Columbus, Salt Lake City, Greenville-Spartanburg-Asheville, San Antonio, West Palm Beach, and Birmingham. These represent the 12 largest DMAs without an NFL team and are listed in descending order of television market size. All are among the 40 largest U.S. television markets, as ranked by the Nielsen Company.1

Most variables included in the model come from Tainsky (2010), modified to tailor his model to markets that do not house an NFL team. The usual distinctions of home and away team employed in many demand estimations are not as relevant to fans from markets not represented in the game. Thus, as opposed to using “home” and “away” to identify teams, in all of the following descriptions TEAM1 represents the team that is closer in proximity to the market whose rating is measured, while TEAM2 represents the team that is further away. The outcome variable RATING represents the Nielsen Company’s computed average of the percentage of viewers watching a telecast in the specified market at any given moment. The company collects its ratings from its stratified sample of U.S. households. Nielsen “families” either record the shows they watch in a diary or a meter is attached to their televisions documenting the same viewership data. Nielsen ratings are widely acknowledged to be the most accurate in television, although a limitation is that they do not include public viewership in sports bars, dormitories, and the like.

The independent variables are meant to account for factors that have been shown to influence demand in previous studies relevant to television viewership in markets without teams along with new ones that are unique to these markets.

In order to account for fan expectations of the competing teams' quality, we introduce the TEAM1QUALITY (TEAM2QUALITY) metric. This metric is a combination of lagged and current winning percentage according to the following formula for game j in year i:
TEAMQUALIT Y

An important property of this metric is that it places more weight on the past season’s performance in the beginning of the new season, while placing equal weight on the past and current season’s performance in the middle, and placing more weight on the current season’s performance late in the season. Uncertainty of outcome is considered in the model via the MATCHUNCERTAINTY metric. This metric for game j is adapted from Bill James' baseball game uncertainty and is given by the equation:
M A T C H U N C E R T A I N I T

and TQ is calculated for Teams 1 and 2 according to the previous TEAMQUALITY equation. This metric has the property of increasing as the relative quality of opponents diverges. Therefore, according to the uncertainty-of-outcome hypothesis, MATCHUNCERTAINTY should be negatively associated with demand.

DIVDUMMY is indicator variable that is equal to unity when the participants are divisional rivals and is zero otherwise, and these games may command a premium. Divisional rivals, however, compete against one another twice per season. Consequently, games consisting of opponents not scheduled to compete each season may be considered unique, making a nondivisional contest more desirable and thus resulting in lower ratings for divisional games.
TEAM1AGE (TEAM2AGE) represents the number of years that the team has been in its home market. This variable captures fan familiarity developing over time versus the novelty of a new team.

The next group of variables is designed to capture variability unique to markets without teams. TEAM1DISTANCE (TEAM2DISTANCE) represents the distance in thousands of miles between the team’s home market and market for which the ratings were measured. This is meant to explain the potential proximity effect. GEOGRAPHICDUMMY is an indicator variable equal to unity when one of the teams in the contest is the closest team geographically to the market generating the ratings. This is included to test whether fans tend to adopt the nearest team relative to their home market when their market has no team of its own. TEAMDISTANCE and GEOGRAPHICDUMMY together establish a closest team and/or regional bias effect.

The final group of variables focuses on timing factors that could potentially affect the decision to watch a particular game. ALTGAME is an indicator variable equal to zero when there is a concurrent NFL telecast and zero otherwise. This is meant to account for the possibility of reduced demand due to a close substitute that is readily available. Also, games contested on Sunday afternoons can be scheduled for either 1:00 or just after 4:00 p.m. (Eastern Time). In order to examine the time slot’s effect on ratings, the indicator variable LATEDUMMY is utilized. LATEDUMMY is equal to unity for games contested in the 4:00 p.m. (Eastern Time) slot and zero for early games. Additionally, to determine whether certain franchises generate higher rates of viewership, dummy variables representing each of the 32 NFL franchises are incorporated into the final model-selection process. Lastly, month dummies are inserted to account for seasonal differences.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: Games played in the same market may not provide entirely independent observations because of market-specific characteristics that could make them more similar from a fan’s standpoint. This seems to be supported by an intraclass correlation coefficient estimate of .093, suggesting a nonnegligible correlation within each of the 12 markets included in the final model.2 Because of within-market correlation the estimation is carried out through a Generalized Linear Mixed-Model formulation and the full covariate model with compound symmetry is fit using maximum-likelihood estimation. The final model is obtained by reducing the maximum-likelihood estimate via backward elimination based on approximate t tests using the Kenward-Rogers correction. The Kenward-Rogers correction is a counter measure for the bias that is introduced by using estimated covariance parameters in formulas that assume these quantities are known (Kenward & Rogers, 1997).

The full model to evaluate demand for game j in year i is given as:

sec.title: Model Interpretation

caption.p: Final Model Results for NFL Ratings in Nonlocal Markets

fn.p: Note: N = 1,296. Cox & Snell’s R 2 = .519. All variables included in the final model are significant at the α < .001 level of statistical significance with the exception of MONTH2 (p = .298), RAIDERS (p = .024), SAINTS (p = .007), and TITANS (p = .006).

caption.p: Viewers Represented by One Rating Point in Designated Market Areas 2006-2007

sec.p: As previous analysis has demonstrated, team quality has a positive impact on ratings. To provide some perspective on the ratings influence of TEAMQUALITY, we compare the most successful team in the sample, the unbeaten New England Patriots late in 2007, to the average team appearing on television, team-quality measure of 0.55. Based on quality alone, replacing New England with an average team would result in a 1.21 point reduction in ratings if the Patriots represent TEAM1 or 1.07 points if they are TEAM2.
MATCHUNCERTAINTY is negative and significant. This provides support to the increased popularity of games featuring evenly matched teams after controlling for quality of the participating teams.

The DIVDUMMY variable is eliminated in the model-selection process due to its high p value. This result may be attributable to opposing forces of opponent novelty versus competition for playoff spots.

Team tenure in its respective market has a positive association with viewership—one additional year TEAM1 or TEAM2 spends in its market increases ratings by 0.03 points. Based on the mean tenure, the average tenured team would draw a rating point higher than a team relatively new to the league.

The significance and parameter estimate of TEAM1DISTANCE would propose a negative association between viewership and geographic distance between the closer team and DMA. TEAM2DISTANCE is discarded early in the model-selection process due to its relatively low significance. Geography seems to play a role in fans without a traditional home team tending to favor the closest team to their own market. This effect is captured by the positive estimate of GEOGRAPHICDUMMY. When one of the teams in the contest is the closest team geographically, viewership increases by 2.48 points.

The significance of ALTGAME provides support for diminished demand in the presence of a close substitute. There is a substantial decrease in ratings, 3.46 points, when there is another game broadcast on a different network. Contrary to some reports in the popular press, the kickoff time’s effect on ratings appears to be nonexistent as the LATEDUMMY is eliminated in the model-selection process.

The significance of MONTH3 and MONTH4 indicates that contests broadcast in the second half of the season exhibit higher ratings relative to broadcasts earlier in the season. The contest timing effect is especially strong for the last quarter of the season, with contests drawing ratings 1.10 points higher during the last quarter than during the first half of the season. This finding is consistent with previous analysis (Tainsky, 2010), where contests broadcast from Thanksgiving week until the season’s conclusion exhibited higher viewership.

Finally, 12 of the dummy variables representing the presence of a particular franchise in the contest are found to be significant at least at the 5% level. The team rating premium, relative to the other 20 teams, ranges from 0.86 points for the New Orleans Saints to 3.92 points for the Dallas Cowboys. This suggests that these select franchises draw larger audiences than their quality attributes already accounted for by other covariates in the model would predict.

The Cox and Snell’s R 2 indicates that 52% of the variability in ratings is explained by the model. This pseudo R 2, an attempt to emulate the properties and interpretation of the R 2, is based on the likelihood ratio of the null model relative to the final model (Nagelkerke, 1991).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study is the first to estimate demand for professional sports in markets without teams. This fan population, which has been overlooked previously in the sport literature and corresponds to over half of the U.S. population, is particularly important to the NFL given the nature and value of its national television contracts. The findings of this research demonstrate there are unique considerations significant in the viewing choice of fans in markets without a local team. Demand is positively associated with team age as well as the presence of select franchises or the closest team geographically, suggesting that familiarity with the teams featured is especially important to these fans. This indicates that just because the fan population researched does not have a local team per se does not mean that they do not identify with certain teams from other markets. Additionally, there are a number of ways in which the fans considered in this study behave similarly to those measured in previous demand estimations. Team quality is positively associated with viewership, while the presence of available substitutes decreases game ratings. The uncertainty-of-outcome hypothesis is supported via decreased viewership for games featuring what promises to be lower relative quality of play.

The estimated model provides important information to the networks and their local affiliates that make no fewer than three game selections weekly in dozens of like markets. In Los Angeles, for example, where a rating point is equivalent to roughly 56,000 television homes, selecting to air the game yielding the highest possible ratings may result in hundreds of thousands of additional viewers versus a less-desirable contest, dramatically increasing subsequent advertising revenues. In this regard, it is vital to understand demand for sports television to capture all of the available dollars within this revenue stream. The results of this study provide evidence that can be beneficial in guiding networks and local affiliates to more effectively select games to broadcast regionally, thus generating increased viewership and, subsequently, advertising revenues.

This analysis is limited to the 12 largest U.S. television markets without an NFL franchise in the 2006 and 2007 seasons. The benefit of our use of population data is that the results are definitive within this group and indicative of markets of similar size. Further, the markets included represent the weekly viewership choices of millions of spectators all across the United States. They are geographically diverse and thus do not present any regional bias. As a result, this research is useful in estimating demand for the majority of the U.S. population residing in markets without teams. Nonetheless, the smallest markets included in our research have roughly 750,000 households. As with any research, caution should be used in extrapolating well beyond the data. We are not familiar with any systematic differences in the sports viewership choices between large and small cities. If, however, these exist, then our findings would be limited in their application to larger markets. Similarly, these results are applicable to the 2006 and 2007 seasons. The principle of certain teams drawing greater ratings certainly holds, but the particular teams may vary across time. Future research using different seasons should consider the principle of premiums for certain teams although not necessarily the ones found to be significant in this study.

As discussed previously, more than 60 studies were identified examining demand for sport-utilizing attendance to operationalize demand. By contrast, relatively few studies have examined demand for sport as measured by television viewership. While thousands of spectators may attend an NFL game, millions of others watch the televised broadcast of the same game. Accordingly, much more investigation is needed to understand determinants of demand for televised sporting events. Further, additional research is needed to understand NFL game selection with its regional broadcasts, particularly in markets without NFL franchises. Subsequent investigation could reveal whether the national television networks and local affiliates are accurately choosing to broadcast the games yielding the highest ratings. Finally, although the NFL is the only league to capture more than half of its revenues via television, broadcasting agreements represent a substantial portion of total revenues for each of the major professional leagues as well as several intercollegiate sports. Future research is needed to measure nonlocal broadcast demand for MLB, NBA, NHL, and NCAA football and basketball as broadcasts of teams outside their local markets will undoubtedly continue to be an important revenue source for these leagues.

ack.title: Acknowledgment
ack.p: We are grateful to Jason Winfree, participants of the North American Society for Sport Management Conference, Tampa, Florida, and two anonymous referees for their insightful comments and suggestions. Mateusz Jasielec provided excellent research assistance.

fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

The Nielsen Company ranks its 210 DMAs according to size. The company provided ratings data on all of the top 40 markets, most of the next 24 largest markets and none with a market rank of 65 or lower. Sampling from the pool of markets 1–64 brings in selection bias as there may exist differences between those made available by Nielsen and those not. We have chosen instead to only use the population data on the smaller dataset (only markets 1–40) in order to avoid any sampling issues. Because the previous literature on sports demand is concentrated on markets with teams, using only larger markets in our study focuses this work on markets of comparable size to those with teams. Findings of exploratory work using a sample of markets 1–64 are available upon request and are similar to those reported in this article.
The intraclass correlation was calculated according to the following equations (Snijders & Bosker, 1999, pp. 18–20):
